dataset.title: Light-fast Performance of Coated Handmade Papers

creator.organizationName: Division of Wood Cellulose, Taiwan Forestry Research Institute

abstract.para: The purpose of the study was to prepare Fenglachien papers, a kind of high-caliber coated paper mostly for Chinese calligraphic use made of coated handmade paper. The parameters studied for the coating and color formulations included the base papers, white complex pigments, various hued pigments and their concentrations, binders, and additives such as a wax emulsion, an insolubilizer, and a photostabilizer. All coated papers were evaluated for their light-fastness through UV irradiation, as this is one of the most important preservation characteristics for colored Fenglachien papers. We also tested the light-fastness of glossy golden- and silver-colored pearlite pigments used for color-painting and pattern-printing on the coated papers. The results indicated that the 2 kinds of base papers performed differently in terms of the white and colored pigments. The colored pigments interacted with the binders in complicated ways, and there appeared to be no rule for the changes observed. For the same colors, a more-saturated hue had better light-fastness than a paler hue. Among the white pigments, precipitated silica had the best light-fastness performance, while titanium dioxide fared the worst. The wax emulsion and insolubilizer contributed positively to the light-fastness of the Fenglachien papers. The tested photostabilizers, however, did not appear to have the anticipated efficacy. Certain synthetic golden pigments showed good light-fastness that allowed for the substitution for actual gold foil flakes for pattern-printing of Fenglachien graphic designs.

section.title: Materials
section.para: Two kinds of base paper for coating were hand made. The fiber compositions of the 2 papers were 50% Chinese alpine rush (Eulaliopsis binata), and 50% mitsumata (Edgeworthia papyrifera) or gampi (Wikstroemia indica), respectively. The papers are referred to as mitsumata and gampi paper in the subsequent text. Unless otherwise specified, the mitsumata and alpine rush fiber blend was used for forming handmade sheets which had an average basis weight of 35 g m-2.

White pigments used for coating colors (meaning the coating slurry) included calcium carbonate (Yuncheng Chemicals, Tainan, Taiwan), titanium dioxide (Hayashi Pure Chemicals, Osaka, Japan), and precipitated silica (Tokuyama Chemicals, Yamaguchi, Japan); the colored pigments designated PY108, PY42 (yellow), PR101, PR122, PR285 (red), PG7 (green), and PV19 (violet) were the products of BASF (Darmstadt, Germany). In addition, PG4201 was a product of Fongtsai (Tainan, Taiwan); and PBr (brown) was prepared by blending PY108, PY42, PR101, and PB15 at ratios of 8: 220: 32: 3 to give a brown colorant.

Binders examined included polyvinyl alcohol (PVA, Yinyuan Chemicals, Taipei, Taiwan), animal glue (Gelita, Baden, Germany), and 2 acrylic resins (P103L and AT40-2, from Chanshieh, Taipei, Taiwan). Other ingredients included an insolubilizer (ammonium zirconium carbonate, AZC; Akzo Nobel, Taichung, Taiwan), a carnauba wax emulsion (Yinshiang, Taipei, Taiwan), and a photostabilizer (Tinuvin 292, Ciba, Basel, Switzerland).

The golden- and siliver-pearlite pigment pastes for pattern-printing examined included real gold foil flakes for control (Jiangszeshutang, Suzhou, China), and most other pearlite pigments were products of Merck (Darmstadt, Germany).

section.title: Methods
section.para: A K-control coater, model KCC 101 (RK Print-Coat Instruments, Litlington, UK) was used to apply the coating colors onto the base papers. A no. 4 coat rod was adopted, and the coating speed was 5 cm s-1. When the variables were not specified, then a blend of 60 parts calcium carbonate and 20 parts each of titanium dioxide and precipitated silica was used for the white pigment coating color. The basic color formula consisted of 14 parts of pigments and the rest was AT40-2 acrylic resin binder. In addition, 4% each of AZC and the wax emulsion with respect to the pigment fraction was added. No photostabilizer was added to the basic formulation. After coating, the coated sheets were air-dried, then calendered using a linear nip pressure of 150 kg cm-1 at room temperature. After 3 passes through the nip, the linear pressure was increased to 200 kg cm-1 and a further 2 passes were carried out. Other test specimens were calendered using identical conditions. When the white pigments were varied, the eliminated titanium dioxide or precipitated silica was replaced with the same amount of calcium carbonate. When testing various colored pigments, the low-, mid-, and high-concentration conditions referred to blending 10%, 35%, and 65% of the colored pigments to 100% of the white pigment base.

The finished papers were tested using a BYK Gardner gloss meter (Geretsried, Germany) to measure gloss at 75°. All coated papers were suspended under the QUV/basic mode in a Q-panel instrument (Cleveland, OH, USA) to undergo the light-fastness test. UVA-340 light sources and a black panel temperature of 50℃ were used. Testing lasted for 1, 3, 6, and 12 d, and the before- and after-treatment color changes of the specimens were tested using a Minolta CM-3630 colorimeter (Osaka, Japan). Since the variables examined were quite numerous, only the color difference values of the 12-d treatments are shown to delineate the relative light-fastness of individual variables.
